    <h2 style="margin-top: 0;">Animal Behaviour in a Changing World</h2>

    <div class="research-img research-img--left">
      <img src="images/slideshow/slide1.jpg" alt="Animal communication research: placeholder image">
    </div>
    <p>We study how animals respond to the rapid environmental changes caused by human activities. A central focus of our work is <a href="research-communication.html">animal communication</a>, specifically how signals evolve, function, and adapt when the world around them changes. We are particularly interested in how <a href="research-noise.html">anthropogenic noise</a> disrupts communication and behaviour across terrestrial and aquatic systems.</p>

    <div class="clear"></div>
    <div class="research-img research-img--right">
      <img src="images/slideshow/slide2.jpg" alt="Noise pollution research: placeholder image">
    </div>
    <p>To draw robust conclusions across species and systems, we use <a href="research-meta-analysis.html">meta-analytical approaches</a> that synthesise findings from studies worldwide, allowing us to identify broad patterns in how wildlife responds to human-induced change.</p>

    <div class="clear"></div>

    <p>Based at Queen's University Belfast, our group combines behavioural ecology, conservation biology, and quantitative methods to address some of the most pressing challenges facing wildlife today.
